posts.name: Tina
posts.cooked: Hi, Anybody can help our team little young programmer 14 years older, he want to know:Distance per pulse to return from -180 to 180 For andymark Swerve & steer Am-3009 Thanks

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
According to the product page , it uses a PG-71 motor to drive a 48-tooth gear, that meshes with a 40-tooth gear, which directly drives the rotation of the pod.  This means you have a 48:40, or 1.2:1, reduction.

The PG-71 includes a hall-effect encoder that returns 7 pulses per rotation .

Now, assuming I read those pages correctly…

Since the encoder is measuring the motor rotations directly, we can do some simple algebra

You can cancel out the “rotation” and “tooth” units, then you get (48*360) / (7*40) or about 61.7 degrees per pulse.

The product page does give other options, so you’ll have to confirm specifically what motors/sensors you’re using, find the specifications, then do the same math as above but with the appropriate numbers…

I hope this helps!

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked:
FYI, you’ll also need to include the ratio of the particular PG71 gearmotor that is included in the kit. AndyMark offers several different reductions and I don’t see anything on the webpage or guide that specifies the reduction that was included in the Swerve & Steer. Someone would need to go into the CAD and try to find a part number or measure it.

Also, looks like the final steering reduction is flipped, with the 40t gear being the output. That would be a 0.83:1 reduction.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Ah yes, good call. I forgot that motor has a built-in gearbox so the encoder would need to be added in.

As for the 48:40, I likely just had my notation reversed.  My calculations were taking into account that the 40t gear was on the wheel-side as opposed to the motor-side of that meshing.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Do you have the “optional absolute encoder”? If so, you shouldn’t have to take the gearing into account, I believe it directly reads the module rotation.

If I understand correctly, without the optional absolute encoder you would have to be sure your robot always boots up with the wheels pointing in a known direction!

posts.name: Tina
posts.cooked: Thanks, I’ll forward it to our little programmer, waiting for him get out of the school.

posts.name: Tina
posts.cooked:
steering: use  PG71 gearmotor. PG: The incremental encoder on the backside of the PG71, this encoder can be used to determine the steering angle provided that all the modules start facing forward.

Hall Effect Encoder for PG motors with longer backshaft.

Thanks

posts.name: NathanNFM
posts.cooked:
Hi Tina, I saw this thread and also got your support ticket, so I will answer here so that if others have the same question they can find the answer. According to the SKU you purchaced (am-3009_XPPA) you are using the encoder on the back of the PG motor. This gearmotor has an exact reduction of 226233 / 3179 : 1 (AKA ~71:1) Past the motor there is an overdrive of 40/48 : 1

We multuply both these gear ratios together, along with the encoder pulse per rotation value of 7

Wolfram|Alpha brings expert-level knowledge and capabilities to the broadest possible range of people—spanning all professions and education levels.

…and get ~415.1 pulses per rotation.

Let me know if you have any more questions!

posts.name: Tina
posts.cooked: I forward to our little programmer, he got the answer. Thanks a lot.

posts.name: Tina
posts.cooked:
Thanks for the information, the wheer can steer, but hard to coding. so our team 14 years old boy  want to try two solutions,

use sparkmax as steering PG 71 motor controller.

use NEO 550 instead of PG 71 steering motor and use sparkmax controller, he is not sure if these two steps are better for coding? Thanks
